subject: MANTA-3228 "mgenazconfig.js" should be able to create a Manta networking config file MANTA-3231 Missing sprintf arg in warning when server is missing from Triton data Reviewed by: Dave Pacheco <dap@joyent.com> Approved by: Dave Pacheco <dap@joyent.com>
commitMessage:
MANTA-3228 "mgenazconfig.js" should be able to create a Manta networking config file
MANTA-3231 Missing sprintf arg in warning when server is missing from Triton data
Reviewed by: Dave Pacheco <dap@joyent.com>
Approved by: Dave Pacheco <dap@joyent.com>

Uploaded patch set 4.

Patch Set 4: CI-Testing+1

"make check" passed ok

Patch Set 4:

It turns out NAPI is not yet required, where I can actually just make use of Device 42 data. In the future I'd like to cross-check against some NAPI data (VNICs, NIC tags, networks, etc.), but this shouldn't make a difference to initially generating a full configuration file.

I've documented some testing notes in MANTA-3228.

Patch Set 4:

(8 comments)

These are mostly suggestions, though I would like to incorporate the docs into the README (or else figure out some other structure for them).  Right now, it seems second-class having the docs separate.

Patch Set 4:

Also about testing: do we have enough information about SPC AMS to generate a config file for that and see if it seems reasonable?
Uploaded patch set 5.

Patch Set 5: CI-Testing+1

"make check" passed ok

Patch Set 5:

(8 comments)

Thanks for the feedback! I believe I've replied to each comment.

I've got a local config that has AMS information now, but it looks like Device 42 isn't quite ready yet. It seems some servers are at least missing UUIDs and both `gen-manta` and `gen-manta-net` bail in different places.

I've not dug too far into that yet, but I don't know what kind of assumptions we make about Device 42 data.

Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)
Uploaded patch set 6.

Patch Set 6: CI-Testing-1

(3 comments)

"make check" exited with status 2
Uploaded patch set 7.

Patch Set 7: CI-Testing+1

"make check" passed ok
Uploaded patch set 8.

Patch Set 8: CI-Testing+1

"make check" passed ok

Patch Set 8:

PS8 addresses my oversight in expecting Device 42 to contain Triton UUIDs. The schema recognises this, but my change did not, so I've used serial numbers in place of UUIDs where they are missing.

This came about by testing against SPC AMS data where `gen-manta` hit a minor bug (MANTA-3231), and `gen-manta-net` complained about a lack of "device.d42d_uuid" in my "mgGenNicMapping" function.

I've been able to generate sample config for SPC AMS via `gen-manta` (which looks sane when passed to `manta-adm genconfig`) and `gen-manta-net`.
Uploaded patch set 9.

Patch Set 9: CI-Testing+1

"make check" passed ok

Patch Set 9:

Dave, sorry for the burst of changes here. PS8 addresses the code changes, and PS9 removes the document I added for `gen-manta-net` in favour of an updated README. I think what's there is lightweight enough for a README and contains enough information to allow readers to use the `gen-manta-net` command.

I've done some re-runs of `gen-manta` and `gen-manta-net` against spc-east and spc-ams data and they look OK. spc-ams is still missing some data in Device42, but both subcommands now handle this well and report the applicable warnings to the user.

Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1 Integration-Approval+1

(1 comment)
Uploaded patch set 10: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by Richard Bradley
warning: variable is declared but never referenced: comparators
unparenthesized return expression
line > 80 characters
unparenthesized return expression
unparenthesized return expression

Given that we produce named output files already (i.e., we're not limited to only one output stream like stdout), what do you think about leaving out this argument and having this emit one output file for each AZ?
I hadn't considered this, but I prefer it. Fixed in PS5. Thanks for the suggestion!
The conditions here are a little odd.  It looks like the second "if" meant to say "< 2"?  Otherwise, I don't see how the third "if" condition would ever be true.
You're right on the typo here, thanks for catching it! Now that AZ has been dropped from that args list (PS5) these checks have been fixed/changed.
It seems like this step might be superfluous?  I don't see any uses of mgo_cns_by_az in this subcommand or mgo_networks_by_az anywhere.

I overlooked the removal of these declarations which came from an earlier attempt at this change.

`gen-manta-net` doesn't make use of Triton data yet and I had planned on keeping this here for future use. I've removed it in PS5 though, and I'll re-add this once Triton data is required for more cross checks at a later time.
It may be worth asserting that `n` is a property of the "networking" object, and that's guaranteed because the schema must match mgNetworkNames.  (Assuming I've got that right.)
Done, including in the sub-forEach that happens per network, which I think it appropriate.

I don't think there's an official style rule about this but I think it's clearer to put the "." at the end of the previous line (and maybe the forEach too here).  Or put the list into a variable to break it up into two lines (e.g., "azdevices").
With the new outer loop replacing "mgopts.mgo_config_az" I've got this down to one line in PS5.
This indent isn't right (and it sounds like jsstyle is confused to not warn about it).
Thanks for spotting that. It was incorrect pretty much all the way past this point for some reason. Fixed in PS5.
Is there any reason not to include this information in the README?

The README makes a few statements about how `gen-manta` works which don't apply to `gen-manta-net`, so I kept it separate only because I didn't want readers to assume that all the same information applies to `gen-manta-net`.

I'd like to add this to the README, but I think the README might require a fair amount of re-work to ensure that sections like "Design notes" don't give readers the impression that they apply to all subcommands.

Would you be against having the README be changed to lead with contribution and installation notes, then having a "gen-manta" and "gen-manta-net" headings that contain specific information for each subcommand? I think this would be the least disruptive.

I agree it probably makes sense to have separate sections specific to each command.  I wonder if you could keep the overview early on (adding info about gen-manta-net) and add a few gen-manta-net steps to the synopsis, and then dive into command-specific details.  I just want to make sure that readers get a clear picture of what these tools are for without having to dig too far through the README, and I think it's tough because there are so many levels of "configuration file" involved with Manta setup.

Many of the design notes are common as well, I think.
Would it make sense to do this with manta-adm?  More generally, I've wondered if we can do the networking setup as part of manta-init/manta-adm?

`manta-adm` should certainly be responsible for this procedure, but while `manta-net.sh` is still required in Manta setup I think this would be useful in `manta-genazconfig`.

This was basically the reason for RFD 76, where I've found maintaining JSON configuration files across the lifetime of an installation to be quite difficult, especially for different customers, and especially when the configuration file is >1000 lines long. `manta-genazconfig` helps with this tremendously for our use.

With MANTA-3014, `manta-net.sh` no longer makes heavy use of `sdc-oneachnode` (if fabrics are enabled), where instead the VNICs are simply created in NAPI, similar to how fabrics are setup in Triton. I've made a start on getting `manta-adm` to do this but it'll be longer before `manta-net.sh` can be fully replaced, mostly due to the mass NIC tagging it's able to perform.
This line should be re-wrapped.
warning: undeclared identifier: nMissingUuid
warning: undeclared identifier: nMissingUuid
warning: undeclared identifier: nMissingUuid
The diagram above makes it look a bit like the output of manta-net feeds into gen-manta, but hopefully this sentence clarifies that.  +1'ing -- I don't want to overly fixate on the docs here.
